importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication, indicating when the charges were officially reported and publicized by CNN.
The start of federal investigation into Andrew Stanton's online activity, triggered by a tip from the Wisconsin Statewide Intelligence Center.
The date when a US Customs and Border Patrol supervisor attempted to contact Stanton, leading to a hostile response and further escalation of the case.
The scheduled pretrial conference date for Andrew Stanton's case.
The scheduled trial date for Andrew Stanton, indicating the timeline of legal proceedings.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period during which Andrew Stanton posted threatening TikTok videos, prompting federal authorities to initiate an investigation into potential threats against ICE agents.

keyTakeAways: A Wisconsin man, Andrew Stanton, was charged with threatening to assault, kidnap, or murder a U.S. official after posting TikTok videos calling for the killing of ICE agents.
Stanton allegedly called for violence against federal immigration agents, including a specific reference to 'shooting at you' when ICE agents appear in a neighborhood.
He also allegedly suggested mass shootings of federal agents and referenced the September 10 murder of Charlie Kirk, saying 'do a lot more Charlie Kirks'.
Federal investigators were alerted by the Wisconsin Statewide Intelligence Center, which flagged a request from Stanton for information about Israeli military locations in Wisconsin and Illinois.
Stanton refused multiple attempts by federal law enforcement to speak with him, including a direct text from a US Customs and Border Patrol supervisor on September 11.
He was arrested and indicted on three federal charges, including threats against U.S. officials, and is currently in detention pending trial.
A pretrial conference is scheduled for December 1, 2025, with a trial set for December 15, 2025.
His attorney, John Bradley, stated that criminal complaints are allegations and that Stanton is presumed innocent and will defend himself vigorously.

namedEntities.name: Andrew Stanton
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A 38-year-old man from Kenosha, Wisconsin, charged with threatening federal law enforcement agents via TikTok videos.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He is the central figure in the case, the individual accused of making violent threats against ICE agents, making him directly relevant to the incident and legal proceedings.

namedEntities.name: ICE (Immigration and Customs Enforcement)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A U.S. federal law enforcement agency responsible for immigration enforcement and border control.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The target of Stanton’s threats, highlighting concerns about the safety of federal agents during ongoing immigration enforcement operations.

namedEntities.name: Charlie Kirk
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A conservative political activist who was murdered on September 10, 2025.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Stanton allegedly referenced the murder of Charlie Kirk in a video, suggesting a possible ideological or violent connection to his own actions.

namedEntities.name: Wisconsin Statewide Intelligence Center
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A federal office that tracks suspected terror activity and suspicious behavior.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It provided the initial tip that led federal investigators to monitor Andrew Stanton’s online activity.

namedEntities.name: U.S. Customs and Border Patrol
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A federal law enforcement agency under DHS responsible for border security.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: A supervisor from this agency attempted to contact Stanton, which escalated the situation and provided evidence of hostile interaction.

namedEntities.name: John Bradley
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He responded to the allegations by emphasizing the legal principle that criminal complaints are allegations and not proof of guilt.

namedEntities.name: CNN
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A major international news network that reported on the case.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It provided media coverage of the case, increasing public awareness and informing the public about threats to federal agents.

namedEntities.name: Department of Homeland Security (DHS)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The federal agency overseeing immigration and border enforcement operations.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is cited as having stated that immigration agents are facing a surge in attacks, which provides context to the broader national environment of concern.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Andrew Stanton, a 38-year-old man from Kenosha, Wisconsin, has been charged with threatening to assault, kidnap, or murder U.S. federal officials, specifically immigration agents from ICE, after posting a series of TikTok videos between August and October 2025. In one video, he allegedly urged people to shoot ICE agents when they appear in neighborhoods, and in another, he referenced the murder of conservative political activist Charlie Kirk, saying 'do a lot more Charlie Kirks.' Federal investigators became aware of his activities after a tip from the Wisconsin Statewide Intelligence Center, which flagged a request for Israeli military locations. Despite multiple attempts by federal agents to contact him, including a direct text from a U.S. Customs and Border Patrol supervisor on September 11, Stanton refused communication and sent hostile messages. He was arrested and indicted on three federal counts, including threats against a U.S. official, and remains in detention pending trial. A pretrial hearing is scheduled for December 1, 2025, and a trial is set for December 15, 2025. His attorney, John Bradley, maintains that the criminal complaint is based on allegations and that Stanton is presumed innocent.
title: Wisconsin man charged after posting TikTok videos calling for the killing of ICE agents, prosecutors say
